column1: # This file contains which conditions to plot and which color will be used for each condition
# You can add as much conditions as you want to delineate
column2: as long as these conditions are an element of `Input.conditions` in the parameter file
`Color` must be a CSS color in matplotlib (see https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/color/named_colors.html)

column1: # Use color gradients when you have several timepoints and you want to follow the phenotypic progression in the spectrum

column2: `Color` must be a preset colormap in matplotlib
`Color` can either be one color (set as the maximum of the color gradient)

column1: #     or a list of colors separated by `;` (sequence of colors in the gradient from minimum to maximum)
#     and each color name must be a CSS color in matplotlib
# `GradientLimits` sets the minimum and maximum timepoints that will be reflected in the gradient and must be separated by `;`

column2: 0;100 will create a color gradient where the minimum is set at P0 and 100 is set at P100

column1: #     Everything beyond the limits will be colored the same as the limits
